awd_abstract_narration:
The Engineering Technology Challenge (ETC) program is a collaboration among Connecticut community colleges, three inner-city high schools, industry, the Connecticut Business and Industry Association (CBIA), and Catalysts Powering Educational Performance (CPEP Inc.) to engage a diverse group of underrepresented students from urban comprehensive high schools in Saturday and summer programs focused on manufacturing technology. The program will create teams of high school students, mentored by community college students, faculty, and industry professionals in industry-driven problem based learning (PBL) projects, including the integration of professional skills and teamwork. 

Specifically, the ETC Program will develop and implement: 1) after-school programs for high school students, using industry and interest driven PBL projects; 2) career and college readiness workshops; 3) summer learning experiences including industry internships; 4) high school teacher summer workshops using the PBL curriculum and hands-on kits developed in ETC; 5) manufacturing career pathway experiences for career counselors, STEM high school teachers and parents; and 6) participation in Mini Maker Faires. Diversity is a core goal of ETC, directly impacting approximately 240 inner-city/under-represented high school students and 75 high school teachers. Through teacher professional development workshops, another 7500 students are indirectly impacted (~100 students per teacher). ETC will contribute to preparation of students for continuing their career pathway in manufacturing technology through credit certificates and degrees at partner community colleges and universities; and for high-tech jobs in the advanced manufacturing workforce. Project evaluation efforts will contribute to the general knowledge base regarding the attributes and practices of successful after school and summer programs for secondary school students, as well as associated professional development for teachers, that are carried out in collaboration with community college faculty and industry mentors.

por.por_cntn:
The Engineering Technology Challenge (ETC) Program is an NSF/ATE funded project grant that was developed to provide inner-city and under-represented students the opportunity to significantly enhance their technological, math and professional/social skills necessary to achieve in both advanced education and workplace environments. ETC was developed to meet the skill needs identified by a series of surveys conducted by the NSF funded Regional Center for Next Generation Manufacturing (RCNGM) and the Connecticut Business and Industry Association (CBIA). Underlying motivation for ETC was to change the mindset of how the students understand that with effort on their part, they can perform college level work in Industry 4.0. ETC has also been instrumental in the students' realization that technology is fun and that their earning potential far exceeds their expectations.

Typical ETC students are primarily B and C level students who have not yet figured out what they want to be and whether they will advance their education after high school. Because they are three to four years behind their suburban counterparts academically and were in raised in poverty, the ETC Team discusses the financial benefits of starting college at one of Connecticut Community Colleges, a place where they will be able to enhance their skills necessary to meet the rigid academic requirements of a bachelor's degree. The educational discrepancy between suburban students to inner-city students in Connecticut is among the most severe in the United States.

From its inception, approximately 325 students have participated in the five-week Saturday and Summer Workshops at a community college. Due to Covid, the ETC Programs moved to an online format. Students were from the following high schools:  Hartford High School's Academy of Engineering and Green Technology, New Britain High School, New Haven High School, Bloomfield High School, Ansonia High School, West Haven High School, Global Environment Magnet High School, and CREC's Academy of Science and Innovation.

Females accounted for 55% of total ETC enrollment. Black students represented 39% of the total enrollment; Hispanic students 36%; Asian students 8%; and multiracial students 9%. Students are asked to evaluate the overall program and instructors at the end of each program. The overall average rating for ETC was 4.5 points, out of a possible total score of 5.0. In fact, the students have proven to be the best recruiters for the program as they go back to their classrooms to talk about their great experiences.

Over the grant period, various topics were piloted.  The following topics were presented to the students:

Professional/Social Skills:

  • Developing Highly Effective Teams Using the DISC Behavioral Model
  • Emotional Quotient the Master Aptitude
  • Motivators
  • Walking Away from Potential Trouble
  • How to Dress for a Job Interview
  • Introduction to Community Colleges

Student feedback indicated that they found DISC and Emotional Intelligence were the best professional/social skills topics because that assessment and ensuing discussions helped them to better understand themselves as well as others, how to best understand and communicate with others, how to use this tool in a team environment, and how best to deal with adversity and compulsive behavior.

Technical Skills:

  • Solidworks Training (switched to TinkerCAD during online format)
  • Introduction to 3D Printing
  • Coding with BBC Micro:bits
  • Measurements and Metric Conversions
  • Assembling and Programming Co-Drones
  • Introduction to Coding

Students indicated that although Solidworks and 3D Printing were the most helpful, all of the technical topics were interesting.   

The ETC Team recruited successful minority technicians and engineers so that  targeted students can see firsthand how someone that looks like them can overcome poverty and other hardships to become successful in their educations and careers. This part of the program was extremely valuable to the students' awareness of what they are capable of along with tips on how to rise out of poverty, with the understanding that everything worthwhile comes from persistence and hard work.

Due to the COVID pandemic, all Connecticut high schools went to online during the first quarter of 2020, a monumental task as online learning was new to almost all of the school districts where ETC targeted students come from. The ETC Team was prepared and worked to rewrite and adjust the curriculum for online presentations including the need to introduce more hands-on opportunities suitable for an online learning environment.

A Summer Teachers Workshop was held in partnership with RCNGM for most of the grant years. These workshops provided 66 high school teachers, community college and university faculty, and guidance counselors the background to present both the academic subjects as well as the professional/social skills in their classrooms and senior capstone projects. It also provided guidance counselors with the necessary background to help steer students towards technical and engineering disciplines. Workshop participants have rated the ETC Program as 4.6 on a 5-point scale.

 

 


Last Modified: 01/28/2022
Modified by: Mehrdad Faezi
